moves.1. e4 c5 2. Bc4 e6 3. Nc3 Nc6: Slightly strange Sicilian for me, not quite sure how to develop this one, but looking at the obvious d5 at some stage.
moves.4. Nf3 Nf6: Possible threat of 5. e5 here, but I played this anyway -- would be interested to know if 5. e5 is a genuinely nasty move (I was hoping that 5... Ng4 would be enough to counter).
moves.5. d3 d5 6. Bb3 dxe4: This exchange is good, as if 7. Nxe4 Nxe4 8. dxe4 Qxd1 9. Kxd1 leaves white unable to castle with the king stuck on an exposed central file.
moves.7. dxe4: Ah yes, that makes more sense, but this works too, keeping the ability to castle in exchange for a loss of material.
moves.7... Qxd1+ 8. Nxd1 Nxe4: Black is now a pawn ahead.
moves.12. c3 O-O 13. Bxc6 Bxc6 14. Ne5 Bd5: Wanting to keep hold of both bishops, but I think Ra-c1 would have been better...
moves.15. Bg5 h6: Forced, gives an obvious combination for Black to remove a bishop and double my pawns.
moves.16. Bxf6 Bxf6 17. Nd7 Rfd8 18. Nxf6+ gxf: Kind of unpleasant, but at least I still have one more pawn and the open file.
moves.19. Ne3 Bc6: Expecting Ra-d1 now, but Ng4 is an obvious possibility, attacking both pawns.
moves.20. Ng4: As expected, but I cannot see easily how white will continue to attack after Kg7 -- white really wants to get a rook onto the d file to contest for its control.
moves.20... Kg7 21. h3: Really unsure about this move. I simply don't understand the purpose apart from protecting against a back rank mate?
moves.21... Rd2: Awkward choice for white, Re-d1 to sacrifice the b2 pawn and get to Rd7, or protect the pawn.
moves.22. Rab1: Chose to protect the pawn, but tied up another rook in the process.
moves.22... b5: Protecting the c4 square, partly from the white knight as I don't want it to become any more useful than necessary.
moves.23. a3: Presumably this is to prevent b4, but I think, again, that white needs Re-d1 to contest for the d file.
moves.23... Rad8 24. b4: Ah, ok, presumably a3 was to stop the a pawn from hanging after this advance. Now I suspect white wants cxb4 axb4 so that he can attack on the a file.
moves.24... c4: so I will lock the position. Removing the d3 and b3 squares from white, this should make it very hard to defend both the a3 and c3 pawns.
moves.25. Ne3: This is the move I played b5 for, but now the c4 pawn is well and truly awkward for white (though the knight sacrifice is a possibility, 26. Nxc4 bxc4 27. b5 is interesting). d3 looks like a nice place to get my bishop if I can now.
moves.25... Rd8d3: Simple threat against the c3 pawn.
moves.26. Rec1: Defends, but now Ra2 seems to win a pawn, either after Ra1 Rxa1 Rxa1 Rxc3 or simply Rxa3
moves.26... Ra2 27. Rba1 Rxa1 28. Rxa1 Rxc3 29: Now two pawns up, trying to remove white's ability to advance by taking the g4 square away from the knight.
moves.30. g3 Kf6 31. h4 Bf3: The position is now relatively seized up for the moment. h5 is needed to fully lock the kingside, but it is not urgent.
moves.32. a4 a6: bxa4 would definitely be bad, but the exchange if white captures is quite reasonable for white.
moves.33. Rb1: A strange move, losing the b4 pawn. 33... Rb3 34. Rxb3 instead would simply lose the game as the b pawn would queen.
moves.33... Rb3 34. Rc1 Rxb4 35. axb5 axb5: Now three pawns up with a lot of queenside pressure.
moves.36. Ra1 Rb2: Threatening Rxf2 and allowing the c and b pawns to advance.
moves.37. Ra5: I can get a free pawn and keep b5 defended -- now 4 pawns ahead.
moves.37... Rxf2+ 38. Kg1 Rb2 39. Kf1 b4: Time to start the advance. 40. Nxc4 fails to 40... Be2
